title: Labrador
text:
Statistics Lab: One-Sample t-Test
Objective
Students will: ‚Ä¢ Conduct and interpret a one-sample t-test in R (or another platform you prefer). ‚Ä¢ Compare their sample data to a known or hypothesized population mean. ‚Ä¢ Communicate their findings in APA-style format.

title: Labrador
text:
1. Concept Refresher (5‚Äì10 minutes)
Prompt: ‚ÄúSometimes we want to know if a group we‚Äôre studying is different from the general population ‚Äî but we only have one group‚Äôs data. The one-sample t-test helps us test whether our sample mean differs significantly from a known or hypothesized mean.‚Äù
Example questions to warm up: ‚Ä¢ What does the t-test compare? ‚Ä¢ What does the null hypothesis say in this context? ‚Ä¢ How does sample size affect the t statistic?

title: Labrador
section: 2. Example Scenario Ideas (Pick one or rotate by section)
text:
2. Example Scenario Ideas (Pick one or rotate by section)
Each scenario includes a population mean and invites students to test a claim:
Theme Scenario Population Mean (Œº‚ÇÄ) Variable Example üç´ Fun & Food The average American eats 12 pounds of chocolate per year. Is our class different? 12 chocolate_pounds üì± Technology On average, college students spend 4 hours/day on their phone. Is our sample higher? 4 hours_per_day üí§ Sleep The CDC recommends 8 hours of sleep per night. Does our sample get less? 8 sleep_hours üò¨ Anxiety National anxiety scale mean = 50 (SD = 10). Is our class more anxious? 50 anxiety_score

title: Labrador
text:
3. Data Collection (10‚Äì15 minutes)
Option 1: Live data collection Have students submit quick responses via Google Form or Qualtrics (e.g., ‚ÄúHow many hours of sleep did you get last night?‚Äù). Export as a .csv.
Option 2: Simulated dataset Provide a dataset such as:

title: Labrador
text:
4. Analysis (15‚Äì20 minutes)
Step 1: State hypotheses ‚Ä¢ H‚ÇÄ: Œº = Œº‚ÇÄ ‚Ä¢ H‚ÇÅ: Œº ‚â† Œº‚ÇÄ
Step 2: Run the test in R



    One Sample t-test

data:  sleep_data$sleep_hours
t = -5.2258, df = 29, p-value = 1.354e-05
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 8
95 percent confidence interval:
 6.827916 7.487297
sample estimates:
mean of x 
 7.157607 


Step 3: Interpret the output ‚Ä¢ t-value ‚Ä¢ df ‚Ä¢ p-value ‚Ä¢ 95% confidence interval ‚Ä¢ Direction of difference
Step 4: APA write-up example
Students in our sample (M = 7.2, SD = 0.9) reported significantly less sleep than the CDC‚Äôs recommended 8 hours, t(29) = -4.67, p < .001.

title: Labrador
text:
5. Discussion Questions
1.  What does the negative t-value indicate?
2.  What would happen if the sample were larger but had the same mean?
3.  How does the confidence interval help confirm your conclusion?
4.  Can a non-significant result still be meaningful? Why or why not?

title: Labrador
text:
6. Optional Extension
‚Ä¢   Effect Size: Calculate Cohen‚Äôs d manually or using:


[1] -0.9540911


‚Ä¢   Visualization: Show how the sample mean compares to the population mean with a density plot or boxplot.

title: Labrador
text:
Deliverable
A short lab report (or RMarkdown/Quarto doc) including: 1. Stated hypotheses 2. Output and interpretation 3. APA-style results section 4. Visual (optional) 5. Reflection question: ‚ÄúWhat does your result suggest about your sample?‚Äù
